bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, November 20, 1952

div1.p: Hench is delighted with Blossom Reed's diplomatic reply to the Cuban invitation, in which she promoted her father and mentioned Reed's high regard for Finlay. He informs her that the park will be called Camp Lazear, and that this is the first time the Cuban government has honored Reed and his associates.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, November 20, 1952
div1.opener:
November 20, 1952
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I am delighted with your diplomatic reply to the Cuban invitation. You
had every right to speak up for your father and especially to mention
his high regard for Doctor Finlay.

You did not miss the significance of the wording of the letterhead and I
had been anticipating the attitude implied therein. Nevertheless, this
is the first time that the Cuban Government has ever honored your father
and his associates. It is a very good beginning and I am especially
encouraged as I have just received from Doctor Nogueira a letter which
says that “the park is still Camp Lazear and the name of the building is
still Building No. 1 or the fomites building. Up to now that has been
the thinking of the patrons.” In other words, the park will be called
Camp Lazear.

On my return I will write you all about the ceremony and in time, send
you photographs.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
